leanCodeSectionsTree.body: User note: Code change proposals to sections preceded by the designation [F] will be considered by the International Fire Code Development Committee during the 2016 (Group B) Code Development Cycle. See explanation on page iv.

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall specify where fire protection systems are required and shall apply to the design, installation and operation of fire protection systems.

Fire protection systems shall be installed, repaired, operated and maintained in accordance with this code and the International Fire Code.

Any fire protection system for which an exception or reduction to the provisions of this code has been granted shall be considered to be a required system.
Exception: Any fire protection system or portion thereof not required by this code shall be permitted to be installed for partial or complete protection provided that such system meets the requirements of this code.
Persons shall not remove or modify any fire protection system installed or maintained under the provisions of this code or the International Fire Code without approval by the building official.

Threads provided for fire department connections to sprinkler systems, standpipes, yard hydrants or any other fire hose connection shall be compatible with the connections used by the local fire department.

Fire protection systems shall be tested in accordance with the requirements of this code and the International Fire Code. When required, the tests shall be conducted in the presence of the building official. Tests required by this code, the International Fire Code and the standards listed in this code shall be conducted at the expense of the owner or the owner's authorized agent. It shall be unlawful to occupy portions of a structure until the required fire protection systems within that portion of the structure have been tested and approved.
Where required, fire protection systems shall be monitored by an approved supervising station in accordance with NFPA 72.

Automatic sprinkler systems shall be monitored by an approved supervising station.
Exceptions:
  1. A supervising station is not required for automatic sprinkler systems protecting one- and two-family dwellings.
  2. Limited area systems serving fewer than 20 sprinklers.

Fire alarm systems required by the provisions of Section 907.2 of this code and Sections 907.2 and 907.9 of the International Fire Code shall be monitored by an approved supervising station in accordance with Section 907.6.6.
Exceptions:
  1. Single- and multiple-station smoke alarms required by Section 907.2.11.
  2. Smoke detectors in Group I-3 occupancies.
  3. Supervisory service is not required for automatic sprinkler systems in one- and two-family dwellings.
Supervision and monitoring of emergency alarm, detection and automatic fire-extinguishing systems in Group H occupancies shall be in accordance with the International Fire Code.

Where buildings, or portions thereof, are divided into fire areas so as not to exceed the limits established for requiring a fire protection system in accordance with this chapter, such fire areas shall be separated by fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both, having a fire-resistance rating of not less than that determined in accordance with Section 707.3.10.

diagrams.title: Example: Fire Areas (Group M)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Area: The aggregate floor area enclosed and bounded by fire walls, fire barriers, exterior walls or horizontal assemblies of a building. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the fire area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor next above.

When sprinklers are required for a fire area, it does not necessarily make it a "sprinklered building" for use in Chapter 5, unless it is "Sprinklered Throughout" in accordance with NFPA 13, 13R or 13D, as applicable. In addition, the separations are also not necessarily the same concept as separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if the most stringent of each fire rating requirements are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Multi. Occ., Non-Rated vs. Rated Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For non-separated occupancies, Section 508.3.1 states the most restrictive provision of Chapter 9 shall apply to the entire area. Therefore, even though there are no limits to B Occupancy fire areas, when combined with an F-1 Occupancy, for example, the 12,000 sq. ft. limit would apply to the total area of F-1 and B.

UpCodes Note: This is a separate concept from separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if both fire rating requirements are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Additions to Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an existing building's size is increased, it must comply with the fire protection requirements of chapter 9 of the building code. An addition is defined as, "An extension or increase in floor area, number of stories, or height of a building or structure." For building additions, the existing building code must be consulted. Additions are specifically addressed in Ch. 11. The user note at the beginning of this chapter states that,"...contains the minimum requirements for an addition that is not separated from the existing building by a fire wall…"

In our example we have a Group A-2 occupancy that is currently 3,000 sq. ft., as is no fire sprinkler protection is required. An addition to the building will increase the total area to 6,000 sq. ft. Based on the fire protection requirements for a Group A-2 in the building code section 903.2.1.2, an A-2 that exceeds 5,000 sq.ft. is required to be equipped throughout with an automatic fire sprinkler system.

Alternatively, if a fire sprinkler was not to be installed, the new addition could be separated from the existing by a fire-rated wall. As long as each fire area remains below the requirements for sprinklering, none would be required.

children.body: Where provided, fire pump rooms and automatic sprinkler system riser rooms shall be designed with adequate space for all equipment necessary for the installation, as defined by the manufacturer, with sufficient working room around the stationary equipment. Clearances around equipment to elements of permanent construction, including other installed equipment and appliances, shall be sufficient to allow inspection, service, repair or replacement without removing such elements of permanent construction or disabling the function of a required fire-resistance-rated assembly. Fire pump and automatic sprinkler system riser rooms shall be provided with a door(s) and unobstructed passageway large enough to allow removal of the largest piece of equipment.

diagrams.title: Fire Pump Room Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire pump room requirements provide for access for continued maintenance and/or replacement of equipment, prevention of freezing in cold environments, as this is an essential element of the life-safety system when provided.
Space inside the room shall provide sufficient spacing for inspection, servicing, repair and replacement of equipment without altering building/room construction.

diagrams.title: Example: Dry Sprinkler
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A dry sprinkler is a sprinkler secured in an extension nipple that has a seal at the inlet end to prevent water from entering the nipple until the sprinkler operates.

diagrams.title: Equipment Platforms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Equipment platforms by definition have zero occupant load and are elevated platforms that may only be used for mechanical systems equipment or industrial process equipment. Equipment platforms do not contribute to the building area, fire area, or number of stories, and are not considered a portion of the floor below. Elements providing access to the platform such as walkways, stairs, alternating tread devices and ladders may not serve as part of the building's means of egress. Equipment platforms may not be part of a mezzanine.

children.body: Automatic sprinkler systems shall comply with this section.

Alternative automatic fire-extinguishing systems complying with Section 904 shall be permitted instead of automatic sprinkler protection where recognized by the applicable standard and approved by the fire code official.

Approved automatic sprinkler systems in new buildings and structures shall be provided in the locations described in Sections 903.2.1 through 903.2.12.
Exception: Spaces or areas in telecommunications buildings used exclusively for telecommunications equipment, associated electrical power distribution equipment, batteries and standby engines, provided those spaces or areas are equipped throughout with an automatic smoke detection system in accordance with Section 907.2 and are separated from the remainder of the building by not less than 1-hour fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or not less than 2-hour horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings and portions thereof used as Group A occupancies as provided in this section. For Group A-1, A-2, A-3 and A-4 occupancies, the automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout the story where the fire area containing the Group A-1, A-2, A-3 or A-4 occupancy is located, and throughout all stories from the Group A occupancy to, and including, the levels of exit discharge serving the Group A occupancy. For Group A-5 occupancies, the automatic sprinkler system shall be provided in the spaces indicated in Section 903.2.1.5.

diagrams.title: Assembly Occupancies on Roofs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a roof is utilized as an assembly occupancy, depending on the assembly type, occupant load, the building occupancy, and construction type the floors below the occupied roof may have to be equipped with an automatic sprinkler system. For buildings of any construction type and all types of occupancies, if the occupied roof is a group A-2 occupancy and the occupant load exceeds 100 then all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be equipped with a sprinkler system. For buildings of any construction type and all types of occupancies, if the occupied roof is a group A occupancy and the occupant load exceeds 300 then all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be equipped with a sprinkler system. The code does provide an exception, sprinkler protection of the floors below a group A occupied roof is not required when the building below is both an open parking and of type I or II construction.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for fire areas containing Group A-1 occupancies and intervening floors of the building where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. The fire area exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  2. The fire area has an occupant load of 300 or more.
  3. The fire area is located on a floor other than a level of exit discharge serving such occupancies.
  4. The fire area contains a multitheater complex.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for fire areas containing Group A-2 occupancies and intervening floors of the building where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. The fire area exceeds 5,000 square feet (464.5 m2).
  2. The fire area has an occupant load of 100 or more.
  3. The fire area is located on a floor other than a level of exit discharge serving such occupancies.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Additions to Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an existing building's size is increased, it must comply with the fire protection requirements of chapter 9 of the building code. An addition is defined as, "An extension or increase in floor area, number of stories, or height of a building or structure." For building additions, the existing building code must be consulted. Additions are specifically addressed in Ch. 11. The user note at the beginning of this chapter states that,"...contains the minimum requirements for an addition that is not separated from the existing building by a fire wall…"

Based on the fire protection requirements for a Group A-2 in the building code section 903.2.1.2, an A-2 that exceeds 5,000 sq.ft. is required to be equipped throughout with an automatic fire sprinkler system.

Alternatively, if a fire sprinkler was not to be installed, the new addition could be separated from the existing by a fire-rated wall. As long as each fire area remains below the requirements for sprinklering, none would be required.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for fire areas containing Group A-3 occupancies and intervening floors of the building where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. The fire area exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  2. The fire area has an occupant load of 300 or more.
  3. The fire area is located on a floor other than a level of exit discharge serving such occupancies.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Multi. Occ., Non-Rated vs. Rated Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For non-separated occupancies, Section 508.3.1 states the most restrictive provision of Chapter 9 shall apply to the entire area. Therefore, even though there are no limits to B Occupancy fire areas, when combined with an F-1 Occupancy, for example, the 12,000 sq. ft. limit would apply to the total area of F-1 and B.

UpCodes Note: This is a separate concept from separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if both fire rating requirements are met.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for fire areas containing Group A-4 occupancies and intervening floors of the building where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. The fire area exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  2. The fire area has an occupant load of 300 or more.
  3. The fire area is located on a floor other than a level of exit discharge serving such occupancies.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for Group A-5 occupancies in the following areas: concession stands, retail areas, press boxes and other accessory use areas in excess of 1,000 square feet (93 m2).

Where an occupied roof has an assembly occupancy with an occupant load exceeding 100 for Group A-2 and 300 for other Group A occupancies, all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge shall be equipped with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
Exception: Open parking garages of Type I or Type II construction.

diagrams.title: Assembly Occupancies on Roofs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a roof is utilized as an assembly occupancy, depending on the assembly type, occupant load, the building occupancy, and construction type the floors below the occupied roof may have to be equipped with an automatic sprinkler system. For buildings of any construction type and all types of occupancies, if the occupied roof is a group A-2 occupancy and the occupant load exceeds 100 then all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be equipped with a sprinkler system. For buildings of any construction type and all types of occupancies, if the occupied roof is a group A occupancy and the occupant load exceeds 300 then all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be equipped with a sprinkler system. The code does provide an exception, sprinkler protection of the floors below a group A occupied roof is not required when the building below is both an open parking and of type I or II construction.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided where multiple fire areas of Group A-1, A-2, A-3 or A-4 occupancies share exit or exit access components and the combined occupant load of these fire areas is 300 or more.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout the entire floor containing an ambulatory care facility where either of the following conditions exist at any time:
  1. Four or more care recipients are incapable of self-preservation, whether rendered incapable by staff or staff has accepted responsibility for care recipients already incapable.
  2. One or more care recipients that are incapable of self-preservation are located at other than the level of exit discharge serving such a facility.
In buildings where ambulatory care is provided on levels other than the level of exit discharge, an automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout the entire floor where such care is provided as well as all floors below, and all floors between the level of ambulatory care and the nearest level of exit discharge, including the level of exit discharge.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for Group E occupancies as follows:
  1. Throughout all Group E fire areas greater than 12,000 square feet (1115 m2) in area.
  2. Throughout every portion of educational buildings below the lowest level of exit discharge serving that portion of the building.
    Exception: An automatic sprinkler system is not required in any area below the lowest level of exit discharge serving that area where every classroom throughout the building has not fewer than one exterior exit door at ground level.

diagrams.title: Child Care as Group E
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Day cares are typically classified as Group I-4 occupancies. However, they may be classified as a Group E when the building serves a total occupant load of 6-100 persons, under the age of 2-1/2 years, and each room has an exit directly to the outside at the level of exit discharge.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout all buildings containing a Group F-1 occupancy where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. A Group F-1 fire area exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  2. A Group F-1 fire area is located more than three stories above grade plane.
  3. The combined area of all Group F-1 fire areas on all floors, including any mezzanines, exceeds 24,000 square feet (2230 m2).
  4. A Group F-1 occupancy used for the manufacture of upholstered furniture or mattresses exceeds 2,500 square feet (232 m2).

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Multi. Occ., Non-Rated vs. Rated Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For non-separated occupancies, Section 508.3.1 states the most restrictive provision of Chapter 9 shall apply to the entire area. Therefore, even though there are no limits to B Occupancy fire areas, when combined with an F-1 Occupancy, for example, the 12,000 sq. ft. limit would apply to the total area of F-1 and B.

UpCodes Note: This is a separate concept from separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if both fire rating requirements are met.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group F-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sprinkler requirements are determined by a number of different criteria and are dependent on divisions of the building into one or more fire areas. However, in some states, sprinkler requirements may be more restrictive at a local or fire district level. Check with local building and fire jurisdictions to see if local building and/or fire codes have more restrictive requirements, such as for those buildings located in a Wildfire Urban Interface area.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout all Group F-1 occupancy fire areas that contain woodworking operations in excess of 2,500 square feet (232 m2) in area that generate finely divided combustible waste or use finely divided combustible materials.
Automatic sprinkler systems shall be provided in high-hazard occupancies as required in Sections 903.2.5.1 through 903.2.5.3.
An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in Group H occupancies.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout buildings containing Group H-5 occupancies. The design of the sprinkler system shall be not less than that required by this code for the occupancy hazard classifications in accordance with Table 903.2.5.2.

Where the design area of the sprinkler system consists of a corridor protected by one row of sprinklers, the maximum number of sprinklers required to be calculated is 13.
[F] TABLE 903.2.5.2
GROUP H-5 SPRINKLER DESIGN CRITERIA
LOCATION OCCUPANCY HAZARD
CLASSIFICATION
Fabrication areas Ordinary Hazard Group 2
Service corridors Ordinary Hazard Group 2
Storage rooms without dispensing Ordinary Hazard Group 2
Storage rooms with dispensing Extra Hazard Group 2
Corridors Ordinary Hazard Group 2

diagrams.title: Ordinary and Extra Hazard Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: "Classification of occupancies" as used in NFPA 13 should not be confused with the "occupancies" as used in NFPA 101 or the building code. For the purposes of determining the level and design criteria of fire sprinkler protection occupancies are classified by the combustibility, flammability, and potential heat release rates of a building's contents. These occupancy classifications are light hazard, ordinary hazard, and extra hazard.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided in buildings, or portions thereof, where cellulose nitrate film or pyroxylin plastics are manufactured, stored or handled in quantities exceeding 100 pounds (45 kg).

An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings with a Group I fire area.
Exceptions:
  1. An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.2 shall be permitted in Group I-1 Condition 1 facilities.
  2. An automatic sprinkler system is not required where Group I-4 day care facilities are at the level of exit discharge and where every room where care is provided has not fewer than one exterior exit door.
  3. In buildings where Group I-4 day care is provided on levels other than the level of exit discharge, an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 shall be installed on the entire floor where care is provided, all floors between the level of care and the level of exit discharge, and all floors below the level of exit discharge other than areas classified as an open parking garage.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group I - Exceptions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Institutional, Group I, occupancies are those in which people receive care. These include assisted living facilities, hospitals, day cares, correctional and detention centers. Automatic fire sprinklers are required to be installed within these facilities, with the following exceptions: In Condition 1 facilities, where people receiving care are capable of self preservation, an NFPA 13R sprinkler system is permitted to be installed. Sprinklers are not required in daycares, I-4 occupancies, where each room has an exterior door, and the space is located on the level of exit discharge. However, if the I-4 occupancy is located above or below the level of exit discharge, then sprinklers are required to be installed throughout the floor and all floors to and below the level of exit discharge.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings containing a Group M occupancy where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. A Group M fire area exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  2. A Group M fire area is located more than three stories above grade plane.
  3. The combined area of all Group M fire areas on all floors, including any mezzanines, exceeds 24,000 square feet (2230 m2).
  4. A Group M occupancy used for the display and sale of upholstered furniture or mattresses exceeds 5,000 square feet (464 m2).

diagrams.title: Example: Fire Areas (Group M)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Area: The aggregate floor area enclosed and bounded by fire walls, fire barriers, exterior walls or horizontal assemblies of a building. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the fire area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor next above.

When sprinklers are required for a fire area, it does not necessarily make it a "sprinklered building" for use in Chapter 5, unless it is "Sprinklered Throughout" in accordance with NFPA 13, 13R or 13D, as applicable. In addition, the separations are also not necessarily the same concept as separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if the most stringent of each fire rating requirements are met.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group M
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sprinkler requirements are determined by a number of different criteria and are dependent on divisions of the building into one or more fire areas. However, in some states, sprinkler requirements may be more restrictive at a local or fire district level. Check with local building and fire jurisdictions to see if local building and/or fire codes have more restrictive requirements, such as for those buildings located in a Wildfire Urban Interface area.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided in accordance with the International Fire Code in all buildings of Group M where storage of merchandise is in high-piled or rack storage arrays.

diagrams.title: High Piled Storage (definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
High-piled storage refers to storage methods where items are stacked above a certain height, typically more than 12 feet. This can include:
  • Solid-piled storage: Items stacked directly on top of each other.
  • Palletized storage: Use of pallets to stack and organize goods.
  • Rack storage: Systems involving shelving units or racks for organization at various heights.
  • Bin box and shelf storage: Smaller units or shelves that are installed at high levels for additional storage capacity.
These methods maximize vertical space in warehouses or storage facilities, often requiring specific safety and construction considerations.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3 shall be provided throughout all buildings with a Group R fire area.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire sprinklers are required throughout all Group R occupancies. These residential occupancies include hotels, lodging houses, dormitories, timeshare, halfway houses, and similar property uses. The sprinkler systems are to be installed in accordance with NFPA 13 and Section 903.3. However, an NFPA 13D, Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems in One- and Two- Family Dwellings and Manufactured Homes, system can be installed in Group R-3, Group R-4 Condition 1, and Care Facilities with five or less individuals. For Group R-4 Condition 2 facilities, and NFPA 13R, Standard for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems in Low-Rise Residential Occupancies, system can be installed.

diagrams.title: NFPA 13R: Where Permitted
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Use of NFPA 13R sprinklers are limited to R occupancies and may severely limit the allowed height and/or number of stories, especially if also required to be in compliance with the Life Safety Code (NFPA 101) or the 2018 based building codes, even if used in a podium condition.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3 shall be permitted in Group R-3 occupancies.
An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3 shall be permitted in Group R-4 Condition 1 occupancies.

An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.2 shall be permitted in Group R-4 Condition 2 occupancies. Attics shall be protected in accordance with Section 903.2.8.3.1 or 903.2.8.3.2.
Attics used for living purposes, storage or fuel-fired equipment shall be protected throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.2.
children.displayTitle: [F]  903.2.8.3.1 Attics Used for Living Purposes, Storage or Fuel-Fired Equipment
children.titleText: Attics Used for Living Purposes, Storage or Fuel-Fired Equipment

children.body:
Attics not used for living purposes, storage or fuel-fired equipment shall be protected in accordance with one of the following:
  1. Attics protected throughout by a heat detector system arranged to activate the building fire alarm system in accordance with Section 907.2.10.
  2. Attics constructed of noncombustible materials.
  3. Attics constructed of fire-retardant-treated wood framing complying with Section 2303.2.
  4. The automatic sprinkler system shall be extended to provide protection throughout the attic space.
children.displayTitle: [F]  903.2.8.3.2 Attics Not Used for Living Purposes, Storage or Fuel-Fired Equipment
children.titleText: Attics Not Used for Living Purposes, Storage or Fuel-Fired Equipment

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.3 shall be permitted in care facilities with five or fewer individuals in a single-family dwelling.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout all buildings containing a Group S-1 occupancy where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. A Group S-1 fire area exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  2. A Group S-1 fire area is located more than three stories above grade plane.
  3. The combined area of all Group S-1 fire areas on all floors, including any mezzanines, exceeds 24,000 square feet (2230 m2).
  4. A Group S-1 fire area used for the storage of commercial motor vehicles where the fire area exceeds 5,000 square feet (464 m2).
  5. A Group S-1 occupancy used for the storage of upholstered furniture or mattresses exceeds 2,500 square feet (232 m2).

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group S
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Group S-1 occupancies are used for the storage of moderate hazard products. These can include aerosols, paper, boats, lumber, and similar items. Self-storage facilities would also be included in this occupancy classification. Where an S-1 occupancy has a fire area that exceeds 12,000 square feet or where all S-1 areas in a building exceed 24,000 sq. ft. an automatic fire sprinkler system is required. Where an S-1 occupancy is located more than 3 stories above grade a sprinkler system is required. Group S-1 facilities exceeding 5,000 sq. ft. and specifically used for the storage of commercial vehicles (those weighing 10,000 lbs or more, or designed to transport 16 or more people); or exceeding 2,500 sq. ft. and used for the storage of upholstered furniture and mattress require an automatic fire sprinkler system.

Enclosed parking garages that exceed 12,000 sq. ft. or are located beneath other occupancy classifications are required to be protected with an automatic sprinkler system. If the parking garage is located beneath an R-3 occupancy the fire sprinkler system is not required. Where the enclosed parking garage exceeds 5,000 sq. ft. and is used for the parking of commercial vehicles, an automatic fire sprinkler system is required to be installed.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout all buildings used as repair garages in accordance with Section 406, as shown:
  1. Buildings having two or more stories above grade plane, including basements, with a fire area containing a repair garage exceeding 10,000 square feet (929 m2).
  2. Buildings not more than one story above grade plane, with a fire area containing a repair garage exceeding 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  3. Buildings with repair garages servicing vehicles parked in basements.
  4. A Group S-1 fire area used for the repair of commercial motor vehicles where the fire area exceeds 5,000 square feet (464 m2).

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Repair Garages and Tire Storage
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
There are four conditions in which an auto repair garage would require a fire sprinkler system. When a repair garage greater than 10,000 sq.ft. in a building with more than two floors above grade a fire sprinkler system is required. This can be increased to 12,000 sq.ft. if the structure is not more than one story above grade. Any building where vehicles are serviced in basements, and all S-1 occupancies exceeding 5,000 sq.ft. for repair of commercial vehicles require sprinkler protection.

The tire storage threshold is based on volume instead of area. Where tire storage is in excess of 20,000cu.ft. within a structure, the building will require a sprinkler system.

children.body: Buildings and structures where the area for the storage of tires exceeds 20,000 cubic feet (566 m3) shall be equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Repair Garages and Tire Storage
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
There are four conditions in which an auto repair garage would require a fire sprinkler system. When a repair garage greater than 10,000 sq.ft. in a building with more than two floors above grade a fire sprinkler system is required. This can be increased to 12,000 sq.ft. if the structure is not more than one story above grade. Any building where vehicles are serviced in basements, and all S-1 occupancies exceeding 5,000 sq.ft. for repair of commercial vehicles require sprinkler protection.

The tire storage threshold is based on volume instead of area. Where tire storage is in excess of 20,000cu.ft. within a structure, the building will require a sprinkler system.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings classified as enclosed parking garages in accordance with Section 406.6 where either of the following conditions exists:
  1. Where the fire area of the enclosed parking garage exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m2).
  2. Where the enclosed parking garage is located beneath other groups.
Exception: Enclosed parking garages located beneath Group R-3 occupancies.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Open Parking Garage: a structure or portion of a structure with openings on two or more exterior walls that is used for the parking or storage of private motor vehicles.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group S
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Group S-1 occupancies are used for the storage of moderate hazard products. These can include aerosols, paper, boats, lumber, and similar items. Self-storage facilities would also be included in this occupancy classification. Where an S-1 occupancy has a fire area that exceeds 12,000 square feet or where all S-1 areas in a building exceed 24,000 sq. ft. an automatic fire sprinkler system is required. Where an S-1 occupancy is located more than 3 stories above grade a sprinkler system is required. Group S-1 facilities exceeding 5,000 sq. ft. and specifically used for the storage of commercial vehicles (those weighing 10,000 lbs or more, or designed to transport 16 or more people); or exceeding 2,500 sq. ft. and used for the storage of upholstered furniture and mattress require an automatic fire sprinkler system.

Enclosed parking garages that exceed 12,000 sq. ft. or are located beneath other occupancy classifications are required to be protected with an automatic sprinkler system. If the parking garage is located beneath an R-3 occupancy the fire sprinkler system is not required. Where the enclosed parking garage exceeds 5,000 sq. ft. and is used for the parking of commercial vehicles, an automatic fire sprinkler system is required to be installed.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings used for storage of commercial motor vehicles where the fire area exceeds 5,000 square feet (464 m2).
In all occupancies other than Group U, an automatic sprinkler system shall be installed for building design or hazards in the locations set forth in Sections 903.2.11.1 through 903.2.11.6.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout all stories, including basements, of all buildings where the floor area exceeds 1,500 square feet (139.4 m2) and where there is not provided not fewer than one of the following types of exterior wall openings:
  1. Openings below grade that lead directly to ground level by an exterior stairway complying with Section 1011 or an outside ramp complying with Section 1012. Openings shall be located in each 50 linear feet (15 240 mm), or fraction thereof, of exterior wall in the story on at least one side. The required openings shall be distributed such that the lineal distance between adjacent openings does not exceed 50 feet (15 240 mm).
  2. Openings entirely above the adjoining ground level totaling not less than 20 square feet (1.86 m2) in each 50 linear feet (15 240 mm), or fraction thereof, of exterior wall in the story on at least one side. The required openings shall be distributed such that the lineal distance between adjacent openings does not exceed 50 feet (15 240 mm). The height of the bottom of the clear opening shall not exceed 44 inches (1118 mm) measured from the floor.

diagrams.title: Stories Without Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This section of the code addresses sprinkler requirements for buildings without openings. When a building floor exceeds 1,500 sq.ft. and does not have openings that comply with this section of the code then fire sprinklers are required. For sprinklers to be omitted, minimally, openings as shown must be provided. The idea here is that sprinklers can be omitted because these openings allow for ready egress of occupants, ready access for firefighting, and provides an opening for ventilation of smoke.

children.body: Openings shall have a minimum dimension of not less than 30 inches (762 mm). Such openings shall be accessible to the fire department from the exterior and shall not be obstructed in a manner such that fire fighting or rescue cannot be accomplished from the exterior.

Where openings in a story are provided on only one side and the opposite wall of such story is more than 75 feet (22 860 mm) from such openings, the story shall be equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system, or openings as specified above shall be provided on not fewer than two sides of the story.

Where any portion of a basement is located more than 75 feet (22 860 mm) from openings required by Section 903.2.11.1, or where walls, partitions or other obstructions are installed that restrict the application of water from hose streams, the basement shall be equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system.

An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed at the top of rubbish and linen chutes and in their terminal rooms. Chutes shall have additional sprinkler heads installed at alternate floors and at the lowest intake. Where a rubbish chute extends through a building more than one floor below the lowest intake, the extension shall have sprinklers installed that are recessed from the drop area of the chute and protected from freezing in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1. Such sprinklers shall be installed at alternate floors, beginning with the second level below the last intake and ending with the floor above the discharge. Chute sprinklers shall be accessible for servicing.

diagrams.title: Rubbish and Laundry Chutes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Waste, or rubbish, and linen chutes are required by the building code to be constructed of 1-hour fire rated materials and have equally rated, self or automatic closing, openings. Items can be inserted into the chutes from corridors or chute intake rooms. Chute intake rooms must be 1-hour fire rated with a minimum of 3/4 hour rated openings. Chute discharge or termination points, where the chute inserted items end, must be enclosed within a 1-hour fire rated room. Chutes are required to have a sprinkler head installed in the top of the chute, at every other floor, at the lowest level intake point, and in the discharge, or termination, room. For requirements for new construction, se building code (2018) Section 713.13.

children.body:
An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout buildings that have one or more stories with an occupant load of 30 or more located 55 feet (16 764 mm) or more above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access, measured to the finished floor.
Exceptions:
  1. Open parking structures.
  2. Occupancies in Group F-2.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Bldgs > 55 ft. (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If a building has an occupant load of 30 or more people on any story that is 55 feet or higher, above the lowest level of fire department access - as measured from finished floor to finished floor, then an automatic fire sprinkler system is required. This requirement does not apply to open parking garages or F-2 occupancies, low hazard factory industrial uses.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Bldgs > 55 ft. (Ex. 2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If a building has an occupant load of 30 or more people on any story that is 55 feet or higher, above the lowest level of fire department access - as measured from finished floor to finished floor, then an automatic fire sprinkler system is required. This requirement does not apply to open parking garages or F-2 occupancies, low hazard factory industrial uses.

children.displayTitle: [F]  903.2.11.3 Buildings 55 Feet or More in Height
children.titleText: Buildings 55 Feet or More in Height

children.body:
Where required by the International Mechanical Code, automatic sprinklers shall be provided in ducts conveying hazardous exhaust or flammable or combustible materials.
Exception: Ducts where the largest cross-sectional diameter of the duct is less than 10 inches (254 mm).

diagrams.title: Ductwork with Haz. Exhaust
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where ducts are installed to remove hazardous exhaust from a building or operation the ductwork must be protected with an automatic fire sprinkler system. Hazardous exhaust systems are described in the Mechanical Code, Section 510.2. Systems that would require duct protection include those that would potentially create flammable vapors, gas, fumes, mist, or dust, or toxic or corrosive materials. Sprinkler protection is not required where a system's largest duct cross-section diameter is less than 10".

See Section 510.1 for determination of "hazardous exhaust". It is not considered a "hazardous exhaust system" per Section 510 for "laboratory" IF: Materials with health hazard ranking of 1, 2, 3 or 4 only present in less than 1% of median lethal concentration for acute inhalation toxicity (consult SDS for materials).

510.1 Laboratory Definition: For the purposes of the provisions of Section 510, a laboratory shall be defined as a facility where the use of chemicals is related to testing, analysis, teaching, research or developmental activities. Chemicals are used or synthesized on a non-production basis, rather than in a manufacturing process.

510.2 Exception: Laboratories, as defined in Section 510.1, except where the concentrations listed in Item 1 are exceeded or a vapor, gas, fume, mist or dust with a health hazard rating of 1, 2, 3 or 4 is present in concentrations exceeding 1 percent of the median lethal concentration of the substance for acute inhalation toxicity.

children.body: An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in commercial kitchen exhaust hood and duct systems where an automatic sprinkler system is used to comply with Section 904.

diagrams.title: Type 1 vs. Type 2 Hood
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type I hoods are installed for the removal of grease laden vapors and smoke. This type of hood is required to be installed above commercial cooking equipment. All Type-I hoods are required to be equipped with an approved fire suppression system complying with the Building and Fire Codes (IMC 509.1, UMC 513).

Type II hoods are for exhaust only and are not for the removal of grease. These types of hoods are installed for the removal of heat, steam, or odors. An example of a common installation for these would be over a commercial dishwasher that creates heat and steam.

diagrams.title: Commercial Cooking Sprinklers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Commercial cooking equipment, producing grease laden vapor, require installation of a Type-I exhaust hood (IMC 507, UMC 507). All Type-I hoods are required to be equipped with an approved fire suppression system complying with the Building and Fire Codes (IMC 509.1, UMC 513).

The preferred method for protection of commercial cooking operations and hoods and ducts is a UL300 automatic dry or wet chemical extinguishing system. Requirements for these, and other acceptable protection types, are outlined in Section 904.12 (BC 2012 904.11).

Section 904.12.4 (BC 2012 904.11.4) of the IFC/IBC recognizes wet-pipe, automatic fire sprinklers for protection of commercial cooking operations. Where sprinkler heads protect deep fat fryers, they must be tested and listed in accordance with UL 199E. The production and availability of sprinklers meeting UL 199E is extremely limited. However, cooking equipment other than fryers may be protected using standard spray sprinklers or automatic spray nozzles appropriate for the hazard. The cooking equipment sprinkler can be supplied by the building sprinkler system and shall be equipped with readily accessible indicating control valve proximal to the protected equipment. Unlike pre-engineered wet chemical suppression systems, fire sprinklers will continue operating after fire suppression is achieved. The valve is required to allow isolation of the system after suppression is achieved, while maintaining building sprinklers in service. Installation of fire sprinklers to protect cooking equipment shall be in accordance with NFPA 13. [See also, NFPA 13:8.9, 2019 ed.].

children.body:
In addition to the requirements of Section 903.2, the provisions indicated in Table 903.2.11.6 require the installation of a fire suppression system for certain buildings and areas.

IFC Sprinkler system requirements as set forth in
